sources.description:
Rain (1932) is a pre-Code American drama directed by Lewis Milestone and adapted from W. Somerset Maugham‚Äôs short story Miss Thompson (later retitled Rain). This atmospheric and morally charged film stars Joan Crawford in one of her most daring early roles and Walter Huston as a missionary whose rigid morality collides with human desire and weakness. Presented here in a restored and colorized edition, this public domain classic regains visual depth and accessibility for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond.

Plot Summary:
Set in Pago Pago on the island of Tutuila in American Samoa, the story follows Sadie Thompson (Joan Crawford), a free-spirited and independent woman who arrives at a boarding house during a tropical downpour. While she enjoys the company of American soldiers stationed on the island, her carefree lifestyle draws the ire of Alfred Davidson (Walter Huston), a stern and deeply religious missionary determined to reform her.

Davidson pressures the authorities to deport Sadie to San Francisco, where her troubled past awaits. As the rain falls endlessly and tensions build within the confined space of the boarding house, Davidson‚Äôs self-righteous crusade turns into a battle of wills. Ultimately, his hypocrisy and repressed desires erupt in devastating consequences, leaving Sadie to face both tragedy and transformation.

Film Significance:
Rain (1932) is considered one of the boldest pre-Code films of its era, tackling themes of sexuality, hypocrisy, and repression years before the Hollywood Production Code strictly censored such content. Joan Crawford‚Äôs performance as Sadie Thompson showcased her ability to play complex, morally ambiguous characters and remains a standout role in her early career. Walter Huston‚Äôs portrayal of the fanatical missionary adds a haunting intensity, while Lewis Milestone‚Äôs direction brings a claustrophobic realism that highlights the tension between personal freedom and moral authority.

Although earlier versions of Maugham‚Äôs story had been adapted to film ‚Äî including the silent Sadie Thompson (1928) with Gloria Swanson ‚Äî this 1932 sound version gave new dramatic power to the tale, cementing it as one of the most important pre-Code works. Today, Rain is preserved in the public domain and continues to resonate as both a provocative drama and a critique of rigid morality.

metadata.Plot: For residents on the idyllic South Seas island of Pago Pago, life is simple until a boat arrives carrying two couples, the Davidsons (who are missionaries), the MacPhails and a prostitute named Sadie Thompson. Davidson is more than just a religious zealot; he's a mad man. When the boat, which was en route to another port, is temporarily stranded on the island due to a possible Cholera outbreak on-board, Sadie spends her time "partying" with the American soldiers stationed on the island. Her behavior, however, is more than the Davidsons can stand and soon Mr. Davidson confronts Sadie about her evil ways and offers salvation. When Sadie rebels and the attempted redemption does not go as planned, Davidson arranges to have her sent back to San Francisco, where she fled some years ago due to mysterious personal issues. Davidson soon becomes unhinged and thus begins a series of surprising events which culminate in disaster.
